dt: used to express disappointment, frustration, or disgust

shortdef: —used to express disappointment, frustration, or disgust

dt: {bc}any of numerous rodents ({it}Rattus{/it} and related genera) differing from the related mice especially by considerably larger size
{bc}one who betrays or deserts friends or associates
{bc}a pad over which a woman's hair is arranged
{bc}a person who spends much time in a specified place

et: Middle English {it}rat, ratte{/it}, going back to Old English {it}ræt{/it} (attested once), akin to Old Saxon {it}ratta{/it} "rat," Middle Dutch {it}ratte, rotte{/it}, Old High German {it}ratta, radda, ratza{/it} (feminine weak nouns), also Old High German {it}rato{/it} (masculine weak noun), probably going back to an ablauting paradigm {it}*raþō{/it} (nominative), {it}*rattaz/*ruttaz{/it} (genitive), {it}*radeni/*rudeni{/it} (dative), going back to earlier {it}*(H)rót-ōn, *(H)rt-n-ós, *(H)rt-én-i{/it}, of uncertain origin

The origin of the etymon beyond Germanic is obscure. Regionally in German {it}Ratz{/it} or {it}Ratze{/it} are applied to other animals (as the dormouse and the polecat); if these senses are old, the application of the etymon to rats ({it}Rattus rattus, Rattus norvegicus{/it}) may be secondary. Note that if the base is pre-Germanic {it}*rat-{/it}, there is no connection to either Latin {it}rōdere{/it} "gnaw, nibble, eat away" (see {et_link|rodent|rodent}) or {it}rādere{/it} "scrape, shave" (see {et_link|rase|rase}), as has often been assumed.
shortdef: any of numerous rodents (Rattus and related genera) differing from the related mice especially by considerably larger size

dt: {bc}to betray, desert, or inform on one's associates
{bc}to give (hair) the effect of greater quantity (as by use of a rat)

shortdef: to betray, desert, or inform on one's associates —usually used with on

dt: {bc}a common domestic rat ({it}Rattus norvegicus{/it}) that has been introduced worldwide

shortdef: a common domestic rat (Rattus norvegicus) that has been introduced worldwide —called also Norway rat

dt: {bc}any of a genus ({it}Dipodomys{/it}) of nocturnal burrowing rodents of arid parts of western North America that travel by hopping on their long hind legs and have a long tail and fur-lined cheek pouches

shortdef: any of a genus (Dipodomys) of nocturnal burrowing rodents of arid parts of western North America that travel by hopping on their long hind legs and have a long tail and fur-lined cheek pouches

dt: {bc}any of various burrowing Old World rodents (as of the families Bathyergidae and Muridae) that generally resemble moles in appearance and have large often protruding incisors used for digging {dx}compare {dxt|naked mole rat||}{/dx}

shortdef: any of various burrowing Old World rodents (as of the families Bathyergidae and Muridae) that generally resemble moles in appearance and have large often protruding incisors used for digging

dt: {bc}a mole rat ({it}Heterocephalus glaber{/it} of the family Bathyergidae) found in Ethiopia, Somalia, and Kenya that has nearly hairless wrinkled skin and is practically blind

shortdef: a mole rat (Heterocephalus glaber of the family Bathyergidae) found in Ethiopia, Somalia, and Kenya that has nearly hairless wrinkled skin and is practically blind

dt: {bc}a bushy-tailed rodent ({it}Neotoma cinerea{/it}) of western North America that has well-developed cheek pouches and that hoards food and miscellaneous objects
{bc}a person who collects or hoards especially unneeded items

shortdef: wood rat; especially : a bushy-tailed rodent (Neotoma cinerea) of western North America that has well-developed cheek pouches and that hoards food and miscellaneous objects
a person who collects or hoards especially unneeded items

dt: {bc}a child not yet old enough for school

shortdef: a child not yet old enough for school
